section.title: GMAT R2013a Release Notes
section.para: The General Mission Analysis Tool (GMAT) version R2013a was released in April, 2013. This is the first public release since May 23, 2012, and is the 6th public release for the project. R2013a is a major maintenance release transitioning GMAT from Beta to production quality. In this release:

listitem.para: End user documentation was rewritten and greatly expanded.
Code and documentation was contributed by 11 developers from 3 organizations.

section.title: Licensing
section.para: GMAT is now licensed using Apache License 2.0. According to the Open Source Proliferation Report, Apache License 2.0 is one of the most widely used open source licenses thereby making GMAT compatible with more existing software and projects.

section.title: Major Improvements
section.para: Release R2013a is a major maintenance release of GMAT. Most of our efforts have been devoted to improving the quality of the software and its documentation. This year we made a complete sweep through the system starting by updating engineering specifications for all features, identifying test gaps, writing new tests, addressing known and newly found bugs, and completing user documentation. Here is more detail on what we’ve been up to for this release.

section.title: Tutorials
section.para: The GMAT user guide now contains 5 in-depth tutorials that show you how to use GMAT for end-to-end analysis. The tutorials are designed to teach you how to use GMAT in the context of performing real-world analysis and are intended to take between 30 minutes and several hours to complete. Each tutorial has a difficulty level and an approximate duration listed with any prerequisites in its introduction, and is arranged in a general order of difficulty. The simplest tutorial show shows you how to enter orbital initial conditions and propagate to orbit perigee, more advanced tutorials show how to perform finite maneuver targeting, Mars B-Plane targeting, and lunar flyby optimization.

section.title: Reference Guide
section.para: We have written a complete reference manual for GMAT for R2013a. The reference manual contains detailed information on all GMAT components. When you need detailed information on syntax or application-specific examples, go here.

Complete syntactical specification of the interface
Tables with detailed options, variable ranges and data types, defaults, and expected behavior

section.title: Testing
section.para: We have spent much of our time preparing for R2013a on testing. Our script and GUI-based regression test systems doubled in size in the last year.

listitem.para: Over 6000 new system, validation, and end-to-end script-based tests.

section.para: GUI test are performed using SMARTBEAR’s Test Complete software. Script tests are performed using a custom MATLAB-based test system. A complete execution of the regression test system now takes almost four days of computer time.

section.title: Minor Enhancements
section.para: While most of our effort has been focused on quality for this release, we have included some new features.
ICRF is now supported for input and output of orbit state data
CCSDS ephemeris files are now accessible in the output tab

listitem.para: Improved mouse controls for interactive 3-D graphics.
New axis system for asteroid surveys
Improved system modularization by moving more features to plugins

section.title: Compatibility Changes
section.para: Our last release, R2012a, was beta software. R2013a is mature, production software. We made some changes that may cause backwards compatibility issues with scripts written in previous beta versions. Examples of changes in R2013a that affect backwards compatibility with previous beta versions include:

listitem.para: Missed or invalid user data validation checking
Improperly exposed internal fields and functions
Configuration of some Resources in command mode

section.para: In all cases, we modified GMAT to work correctly as specified in the documentation, but did not always maintain backwards compatibility with previous Beta versions. This was a one-time, “pull of the Band-Aid” approach and future releases will maintain backwards compatibility with R2013a or provide deprecation notifications of features that are no longer supported.

In addition, there were some features that did not meet quality expectations for this release and have been turned off in the release package. Most of these features can be turned on for analysis purposes, but they are not fully tested and should be used with caution.

listitem.para: Orbit designer ( cannot be turned on )

section.para: To turn on these features, see the documentation for the GMAT startup file.

section.title: Known & Fixed Issues
section.para: Over 720 bugs and issues were closed in this release. See the "Critical Issues Fixed for R2013a" report for a list of critical bugs and resolutions for R2013a. See the "Minor Issues Fixed for R2013a" report" for minor issues addressed in R2013a.
All known issues that affect this version of GMAT can be seen in the "Known issues in R2012a" report in JIRA.
